Access to contraception has helped women achieve economic and personal progress. We must continue to protect this vital resource so that women can continue to succeed on their own terms.
Birth control is nearly universal - 87% of women report using contraception at some point in their life.

Studies show that access to birth control opened professional and educational doors for women.
51% of women report that birth control helped them complete their education and 50% report that it helped them keep or get a job.
Access to birth control is preventive health care—access to contraception improves the health of women and their families and is linked to declines in maternal and infant mortality.

Today is the 57th anniversary of the Griswold decision in which SCOTUS first held that the Constitution protects the right to use contraception. 

I introduced a resolution reaffirming the right to access birth control & pushing back on recent attacks on reproductive freedom.
